Award.AwardTitle: A Strategies Project - Seeding the Future: Creating a Green Collar Workforce Through Learning about Indoor Urban Farming Technologies and Alternative Energy Sources

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project develops an interdisciplinary and transformative in- and out of-school science education and technology program that engages high school aged youth and their teachers in 1) the production of food using hydroponics, and 2) the use of green energy technologies (solar, and wind) to power hydroponic systems. This distinctive program integrates food production, a novel model of parental outreach, a focus on green career development, and an authentic reason (growing their own produce for selling at a market) for learning how and why to use alternative energy technologies. The project creates an approach to sustainability in which students not only give back to their community, but are in a position to provide a continuous revenue stream to the school in order to operate their indoor urban garden indefinitely. The partnership with the Boston Youth Environmental Network provides youth opportunities for summer internships with green energy companies. The project builds upon a learning progressions model in which youth gradually learn about complex scientific systems and economic principles throughout their years in the program. Rather than a onetime experience, youth are engaged in a long-term experience building their knowledge and skills regarding science, economics, and college preparedness.

This project has the potential to impact thousands of students informally and over 2000 students (in classrooms) directly with a minimum of 60 students receiving focused and in depth learning experiences during the summer and on weekends during the school year. With the passage of laws encouraging local schools to partner with local farms, the need for locally grown produce will increase; in that context, the program brings the farm to the school in a way that allows food to be grown year round. Thus, a model is developed that any school or informal learning center could adopt to grow their own food while simultaneously creating a living and learning laboratory for youth in their own program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

In this work we estabalished an interdisciplinary science program that supports teachers and youth in both formal and informal settings and engages students in truly interdisciplinary science where students learn and apply aspects of chemistry, physics, biology, economics, and how to conduct long-term scientific research through hydroponics. We developed two-tiered hydroponic systems that enabled teachers to grow produce in their classrooms and engage their students in collecting data regarding what variables impacted plant growth. The out-of-school time component engaged urban youth in: (1) learning how to grow food hydroponically, (2) learning about and producing green energy for the hydroponic systems they build, and (3) how to build and design eletronic systems that would monitor their systems.

Intellectual Merit

We established a strong interdisciplinary that included a counseling psychologist with expertise in career development, an educational researcher with expertise in research methodologies, a science educator with expertise in designing science and technology experiences for youth, an urban ecologist who will ensure that our program is scientifically rigorous, an economics/finance expert to provide our team with the skills to engage students in utilizing basic mathematics to learn how to maximize their profits, strong partnership with schools in the Boston area. This team enabled us to establish youth as "farmers" at markets in the Boston area (see video here: http://stemforall2017.videohall.com/presentations/1001). Over the lifetime of this work youth were presented at four farmers markets around the Boston area.  In having youth at farmers markets we learned that it was not just important for the youth but extremely important to dessiminate the nature and type of work that the youth were engaged in while participating in this work. 

Broader Impacts

The broader impact of our work focuses on the recruitment of low-income youth and youth from underrepresented populations in science. This focus is important because recent reports show that while half of all people from higher-income families have a bachelor’s degree by age 25, just 1 in 10 people from low-income families do, which greatly impacts their socio-economic mobility (Presidents Council of Advisors on Science and Technology, 2014). Further, this work addresses one of the major calls in the recent Presidential Council of Scientific Advisors to the President (PCAST, 2014) that it is “critical to connect more low-income students to post-secondary institutions where youth can succeed and are encouraged to complete their degree once they arrive on campus. Over the lifteime of this work we strove to recruit youth who were not considered the top students in their respective schools.  Over the the lifetime of this award we had 70 students graduate with all of them attending a post-secondary institution.  We also trained over 120 teachers as a direct outcome of this award from across the Northeastern United States. As of submission of this work, 30 of the youth are still studying STEM fields, with many choose to study science as a minor or to do such work as established a hydroponics club at their college, or established a food justice club at their college.  As a result the youth who have participated in our progarm are using their STEM skills to improve their communities and to help to educate others about the value of social justice driven STEM education.
